key_title: Key to the species of Carex

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Rachilla elongated beyond utricle, stiffly hooked at tip; inflorescence always a single spike; involucral bracts absent (lowest fertile glume  often bearing a leaf-like blade); female glumes deciduous

Rachilla not hooked, not produced beyond utricle; inflorescence of 1-many spikes; involucral bracts leaf-like or occasionally glume-like, sometimes absent; female glumes usually persistent, rarely deciduous (as in Carex jackiana)
Leaves U-to crescent-shaped in cross-section, tough
Leaves nearly flat or broadly V-shaped in cross-section or filiform, ± soft
Inflorescence 0.7–3 cm long; spikelets ± crowded (sometimes spread out towards base); tussocks small or culms spread out along rhizome
Inflorescence more than 4 cm long; spikelets somewhat spread out along axis; tussocks rather large with fibrous bases
Leaves 2–3.5 mm wide; culms usually scabrous below inflorescence, 0.8–1.1 mm diam.
Leaves 0.5–1.8 mm wide; culms mostly smooth below inflorescence, 0.2–0.7 mm diam.
Stamens 3; inflorescence 1.5–3 cm long; utricle 1.5–1.8 mm diam.; leaves shorter than culms, 0.8–1.8 mm wide; culms 0.3–0.7 mm diam.
Stamens 2; inflorescence 0.7–1.5 cm long; utricle 0.8–1 mm diam.; leaves exceeding or equalling culms, 0.5–1 mm wide; culms 0.2–0.4 mm diam.
Female glumes persistent; culms scaberulous toward apex
Female glumes deciduous; culms smooth or sometimes scaberulous toward apex
Style 3-fid; nut trigonous
Style 2-fid (occasionally some styles 3-fid within an inflorescence in C. gaudichaudiana, and in C. polyantha); nut lenticular or plano-convex
Inflorescence of a single spike, less than 1.5 cm long
Spikes several to numerous; inflorescence mostly 3–90 cm long
Male part of the spike as long as or longer than the female part and not less conspicuous
Male part of the spike from slightly to much shorter than the female part, always inconspicuous, the spike usually appearing to be wholly female
Spike 7–12 mm long, with many female flowers; lowest bract glume-like
Spike 4–5 mm long, with about 3–6 female flowers; lowest bract leaf-like, exceeding the spike
Spikes in clusters of 2–5 (or occasionally some solitary) at nodes
Spikes solitary at nodes (nodes may be close together)

Female glumes yellow- to red-brown, 3.5–5.5 mm long, 1.5–2 mm wide; spikes lax-flowered below, rather dense-flowered above, 3–5 mm thick in mature fruiting stage, upper spikes with female flowers above male flowers (occasionally with additional male flowers above), uppermost with a long (usually very long), male basal part

Female glumes pale yellow-brown, 4–8 mm long, 2.5–4 mm wide; spikes dense-flowered, 5–8 mm thick in mature fruiting stage, uppermost 1–4 wholly male, rarely with a few female flowers in the terminal spike
Utricles minutely colliculate or papillate all over (x 40)
Utricles smooth, glabrous, or hispid over most of utricle body or hispid only on the shoulders and beak

Spikes distant, 10–35 mm long; upper 1–3 spikes male, erect, sessile; lower spikes female or with male flowers above, short-pedunculate; uppermost spikes male; male glumes oblanceolate, apex rounded or subacute; female glumes 2–3 mm long,  oblong ovate, purple black, with a wide pale midrib and hyaline margin, apex obtuse to subacute; utricles 2–3 mm long; leaves minutely mamillate on lower surface

Spikes sessile, more or less contiguous, 7–25 mm long;  lower spikes female; uppermost spikes with female flowers above male flowers; male glumes lanceolate-elliptic, apex acute; female glumes 3–5 mm long, ovate triangular, asymmetric, dark red brown with pale midrib, apex acuminate or aristate; utricles 3–4.5 mm long; leaves without mamillae on lower surface
Utricles hispid over most of the surface
Utricles glabrous, or hispid only on the shoulders and beak
Mature utricles corky, with impressed nerves
Mature utricles neither corky nor with impressed nerves (utricle may be slightly thickened in C. tasmanica)

Culms extending above the leaf-sheaths for a considerable distance; male spikes 2–15; female spikes mostly distant from one another; female glumes mucronate, dark to very dark red-brown; utricles 4–5 mm long, yellow-brown usually tinged dark red-brown; leaves with marginal prickles ± regularly antrorse

Culms usually hidden in the leaf-sheaths; male spikes 1–4; female spikes usually closely arranged; female glumes not mucronate, yellow- to red-brown; utricles 4–8 mm long, yellow-brown occasionally tinged dark red-brown; leaves with marginal prickles irregular and at 90° to leaf
Leaves faintly to prominently septate-nodulose (septa less obvious when fresh)
Leaves not septate-nodulose
Beak of utricle 2–3 mm long with apex deeply divided into 2 stiff slender teeth 1–1.5 mm long; female glumes with mucro 1.5–4 mm long; plants short-rhizomatous

Beak of utricle 0.3–1.5 mm long with apex truncate or with 2 membranous, short but broad teeth to 0.5–0.7 mm long; female glumes not mucronate or with short mucro 0.5 mm long or if mucro >1 mm long as in Carex riparia then plants long-rhizomatous; plants short- or long-rhizomatous
Female glumes 2–3 mm long; utricles 3–5 mm long including very short beak ca. 0.3–0.4 mm long; plants short-rhizomatous
Female glumes 4–7 mm long; utricles 4–6 mm long including beak 0.5–1.5 mm; plants short- or long-rhizomatous
Plants long-rhizomatous; leaves glaucous on both surfaces; male glumes chestnut-brown; female glumes with mucro 1.5–2 mm long
Plants short-rhizomatous; leaves mid green on both surfaces; male glumes light brown; female glumes with mucro 0.5–1 mm long
Terminal spike with female flowers above male flowers
Terminal spike entirely male, or with female flowers in middle
Male glumes with a mucro as long as or longer than body of the glume
Male glumes not mucronate or with mucro shorter than the body of the glume
Utricles 4.5–6.5 mm long; beak (0.7–)1–2 mm long
Utricles 2–4 mm long; beak 0.5–0.8 mm long

Culms 5–70 cm long, shorter or longer than leaves; ligule faintly red dotted; lowest involucral bract shorter than inflorescence but bracts at upper nodes exceeding inflorescence; glumes obtuse to acute, often shortly mucronate (mostly to 0.5 mm long, occasionally to 1 mm long); utricles dotted red brown; glumes and utricles not deciduous at maturity

Culms 1–3 cm long, much shorter than leaves; ligule without red dots; lowest involucral bract exceeding inflorescence; glumes acute to acuminate, often long mucronate (mucro to 2 mm long); utricles without red dots; glumes and utricles often deciduous at maturity
Leaf apices and bracts becoming withered and curly; ligule usually red dotted
Leaf apices and bracts not withering and curling; ligule with or without red dots

Utricles faintly many-nerved (10–12 nerves per each half or side of utricle body, excluding 2 marginal nerves); plants often long-rhizomatous; leaves rather stiff (before drying); culms mostly enclosed in leaf-sheaths; in chiefly subalpine and alpine grasslands

Utricles often prominently (at least when dry) few-nerved (ca. 6 nerves per each half or side of utricle body, excluding 2 marginal nerves); leaves generally readily pliable (before drying); culms exserted from leaf sheaths; in disturbed habitats

Ligule not tubular (i.e. at the sheath apex, the front face does not extend upwards beyond the point of attachment of the blade margins); male glumes purple brown at least when young; utricles inserted at angle of 45–60° to stem axis

Ligule tubular (i.e. at the sheath apex, the margins of the leaf blade extend downwards, free from the ligular tube) at least at the base of the upper 1 or 2 leaf blades; male glumes orange-brown to red-brown at least when young; utricles inserted at an angle of 75-90° to the stem axis and therefore strongly patent
Inflorescence of a single spike
Spikes 2 to numerous
Culms to 5 cm long, distinctly shorter than leaves
Culms longer than 5 cm, longer than leaves
Female glumes 3.5–4 mm long; lowest involucral bract exceeding inflorescence; plants long-rhizomatous
Female glumes 2.5–3 mm long; lowest involucral bract much shorter than inflorescence; plants short-rhizomatous

Spikes long-cylindric (i.e. much longer than broad), mostly 2–17 cm long (rarely some as short as 0.5 cm but then glumes dark red-brown or blackish), clearly distinct and often distant from each other
Spikes ovoid or short-cylindric (mostly ca. 0.5 cm long, occasionally to 1.5 cm long) or ovate in outline, often densely clustered in inflorescence that is itself often ovoid or short-cylindric
Leaves 4–9 mm wide; spikes mostly 3–17 cm long; utricles nerveless or with few rather faint nerves
Leaves 2–4 mm wide; spikes 0.5–6 cm long; utricles distinctly several-nerved
Uppermost spike male; inflorescence 7–18 cm long; mouth of utricle notched to obliquely truncate, soft-textured, pallid (rarely reddish), occasionally minutely hispid, 0.2–0.3 mm diam.
Uppermost spike with female flowers above male flowers or occasionally entirely male; inflorescence 2–8 cm long; mouth of utricle truncate, firm, blackish, smooth, ca. 0.15 mm diam.
Culms terete to subtrigonous, pith hollow throughout; leaves often reduced and much shorter than culms, usually < 20 cm long; rhizome long
Culms trigonous to triquetrous at least above, solid; leaves well-developed, shorter than or exceeding culms, usually >20 cm long; rhizome short or long

All spikes with male flowers above female flowers (male portion sometimes not conspicuous), or upper spike(s) with male flowers above female flowers or male, and the lower spikes with male flowers above female flowers or occasionally female
Upper spikes with female flowers above male flowers (sometimes only 1 or few male flowers) or wholly female; lower spikes wholly female or with male flowers above or below
Leaf sheath front (inner face) cross-rugulose

Leaf sheath front (inner face) not cross-rugulose (note that the leaf blades and back (dorsal surface) of leaf sheaths are usually septate-nodulose. The dorsal surface of the leaf sheath is only occasionally septate-nodulose in Carex divulsa)
Leaf margins (at least apically) retrorsely scabrous or scabridulous
Leaf margins (at least apically) antrorsely scabrous or scabridulous
Utricles with a thickened corky truncate base
Utricles without a thickened corky truncate base
Inflorescence 5–18 cm long, with lower spikes 1.5–6 cm apart; upper spikes contiguous; male glumes colourless/hyaline
Inflorescence 1–7 cm long, with all spikes contiguous or nearly so; male glumes pale red-brown, dark yellow to red brown with or without hyaline margins
Inflorescence with 15 or more spikes; utricles 4–5 mm long
Inflorescence with 3–12 spikes; utricles 2.2–4.5 mm long
Plants densely caespitose, with short rhizome; spikes all or most male above and female below
Plants with long rhizome; terminal spikes female (sometimes overtopped by male spikelets), intermediate spikes male, lower spikes all female or sometimes male at base
Utricles nerveless or faintly nerved, narrow ovoid to ovoid, 1.0–1.2 mm diam.; lowest involucral bract usually shorter than inflorescence

Utricles prominently nerved (in Victorian plants) (numerous abaxially, fewer adaxially), broad ellipsoid or broad obovoid to ovoid or ellipsoid, 1–2.4 mm diam.; lowest involucral bract lowest involucral bract shorter than or exceeding inflorescence.
Bract of lowermost spike much shorter than the whole inflorescence, glume-like or leaf-like
Bract of lowermost spike leaf-like and far exceeding the whole inflorescence
Female glumes 3.0–4.5 mm long; utricle 3.5–5 mm long, 1.6–2 mm diam.
Female glumes 1.5–2.5 mm long; utricle 2–3.5 mm long, 1–1.5 mm diam.
Inflorescence 5–18 cm long, with lower spikes 1.5–6 cm apart; upper spikes contiguous; utricles not winged
Inflorescence 2–7 cm long, with spikes usually more or less contiguous throughout; utricles winged at least on upper margin
Rhizome long; inflorescence with 15 or more spikes, utricle narrowly winged on upper margins; nut ovoid
Rhizome short; inflorescence with 2–9 spikes, utricle prominently winged; nut narrow-ellipsoid to obovoid or lenticular

Females glumes usually dark brown, brown or red brown with green or paler midrib; glumes shorter, ± equal to or longer than length of utricles, margins of utricles almost covered by glumes; beak tip unwinged; achenes 0.9–1.2 mm diam.; leaf blade 1–3.5 mm wide
Female glumes white-hyaline or silvery brown with green midrib; glumes shorter and narrower than utricles; beak tip winged; achenes 0.6–0.9 mm diam.; leaf blade 3–7 mm wide
Utricle strongly reflexed at maturity, with smooth surface; beak about as long as the body of the utricle, bifurcate or notched with teeth 0.25–0.5 mm long
Utricle somewhat spreading at maturity, minutely colliculate; beak much shorter than the body of the utricle, truncate or shortly split abaxially, minutely scabrous
Glumes hyaline to pale yellow-brown with green midrib; utricles often transversely wrinked at maturity
Glumes orange-brown or pale red-brown, with more or less broad whitish or hyaline margins; utricles never  transversely wrinked at maturity
Culms > 4.5 cm long, always more than half as long as the leaves; spikes usually and obviously several
Culms < 4.5 cm long and not more than half as long as the leaves; spikes often appearing solitary
Inflorescence longer than wide; culms 25–40 cm long; leaves ca. 1 mm wide; utricles 2.5–3 mm long, 1–1.4 mm diam. (a very long, tenuous, filamentous plant)
Inflorescence wider than long; culms 4–20 cm long; leaves  1–2.5 mm wide; utricles 3.2–4.5 mm long, 1.5–2 mm diam.
